channel.title: Forensics on fiskeren.github.io
channel.description: Recent content in Forensics on fiskeren.github.io

item.title: Creating Standalone Artifact Collector
item.description:
I received several positive reactions to my last post about how to perform dead host collections. Therefore, I wanted to follow it up with another post on how to create a standalone collector that can gather artefacts from a running host using Velociraptor.

Velociraptor is an excellent DFIR tool designed to efficiently provide visibility into endpoints. It can operate in a server-agent setup, functioning essentially as an EDR—without the AV, of course—with thousands of hosts. Additionally, it can also serve as a standalone artefact collector.

item.title: Deadhost Investigation and Super Timeline
item.description:
I recently attended a SANS 508 course and got time to play around with Velociraptor, which is an awesome DFIR tool made to efficiently get visibility into endpoints. It can be run in a server/agent setup, essentially working as an EDR with thousands of hosts, and it can also be used as a standalone artifact collector.

In this post, I’ll try to explain how to use the Velociraptor executable as a artefact collector to quickly collect Windows artefacts from a dead host image. After collecting the artefacts, I will show how to create a super timeline using Plaso log2timeline from the evidence collected.
